content: Now, to the REAL Topic..... MissU2 had some great advice there. My wife supported me and my career for 17 1/2 years... 19 if you count our engagement period. There ARE people and groups that are ready, willing, and able to offer support to the Military spouse. One source of support that my Wife always found very helpful was our local Church. A suggestion, if you feel that there is not enough support for YOUR group of spouses, have you considered trying to make it better? Seeking out the Ombudsman and offering to assist, volunteering as such if there is not one doing the job? Don't just get down about it, look for the help that is available, and accept assistance and guidance from those who are and have been dealing with the same issue. I know that I celebrate my Wife's support, and could not have done 20+ years without her. Military Wives are, by definition, a hardy and resourceful bunch. Be proud of what you do. All you talk about is standing by our man,well im hear to say thet when they do come home there is no[none] support at all..So how about givin us who do stand by our men some support and stand by us for once.... Left behind spouses are a fact of Military Life - Comes with the territory! Soldiers are called away to the vast far reached of this planet, and the world is dropped on the shoulders of those who wave good-bye to them...and it hurts, but what do you expected?? Soldiers below Staff Sergeant E-6 should probably be single and unattached, so they can go off to foreign battles, fight, get killed/maimed, and remain as occupiers for indefinite periods of time, while causing the least amount of emotional burden to the society that sent them as possible. That's the way the ancient Roman Legions were, and the British Army during the hayday of their empire - - But that's not going to happen any time soon, with the "All Volunteer" military, the push towards military as a career, and a collapsed economy that has people looking desperately at any quarter for any job... Moms and Dads are flocking towards recruiting offices to find a legitimate way of keeping their kids and themselves form starving - - That said, you need to find a peer group you can fit into in your community of other left behind spouses, and support eachother. Get together often, shop together, help eachother tend kids, cry on eachother's shoulders - literally. Most units have spouse support groups exactly for that purpose. Find yours. If your unit doesn't have one, it should!! Get with the commander and organize one! Get a phone list of other spouses, and start connecting. Whining here won't help much, because we are all too far away. We can turn a ear, but we just as well be on the moon for real face to face help - get with local folk and GO ACTIVE!! Good Luck - - Mystical, me and our 4 week old baby the day I was to leave on orders for Viet Nam - she wasn't too happy either... Wandering and Wondering

content: I seldom go through a day when I don't sing the praises of the military wife. I believe it is one of the toughest, loneliest and under recognized jobs ever. I think the military has made it a shade easier on those "left behind" than it was during my time. You could stay in quarters after the GI left the installation. Both of my tours to Vietnam I had to move my family, three preschoolers the first time and the second time it was with one preschooler and three elementary students, into a city where they knew no one and into a new house. My son, third child, seven year old Thomas with the help of his 10 and 11 year old sisters, wrote a song after I left the second time. I see his face in the sky. I can't touch him and I don't know why. My daddy went away and it hurts when I cry. He's in a war where people die. Then I think my eyes will never dry. I see his face in the sky; I forgot to kiss him good by. The first time he went away, it hurt so much I thought I would die. Daddy, oh daddy please come down from the sky and hold me then I won't cry. I want to be strong, but I'm just a little boy and I want my daddy to tell me a story. I don’t think that is wrong. I see his face in the sky. I can't touch him and I don't know why. My wife mad a decision, not to send it to me. She thought it would be too hard on me. She was right. But, she said it was on her night table and she read it so many times that she was afraid that she might rub it out. If I did anything good or if I did anything right or if I did anything that was honorable in the past 50 years it was because this magnificent woman, Julia, who was always there. She is my strength, my wisdom and my biggest cheerleader. The military spouse is a true American hero. OAL God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: Yup, I took Mystical back to our hometown, and she was going to live with my parents in their little three bedroom home, because her own parents didn't have any room, with two teenagers still living at home in their similar two bedroom home. About the only advantage this had was that she would be back in the little town where she was raised with all her friends, and familiar places about her. She had only been out of highschool a 2 years... When I got diverted to Germany, I quickly made arrangements for her to follow me there. It was good for both of us in some ways, but terrible for her in others. She had to make the whole trip with the baby alone, quite a daunting an epic journey in and of itself, but she did it without complaint. She had to live in a little German apartment 10 miles from post and survive/learn the language without much help from anywhere. She had to endure as much as 50 days alone at a time, when our tank unit would go off to places like the border, or Grafenwohr, for long periods of training. She had to endure being hit-on by all the "Stay-behind SOBs" that troll for lonely, vulnerable spouses while the real troops are off slogging and sleeping in the !#@%%!% snow!! - - And she did all that with loving help from the wives of CMSs, Cols, SFCs, Capts, and other Sgts, who pulled together as tight as Platoons to baby sit for eachother, help eachother with laundry, shop together, and just sit around and chatter/cry together - THAT was a Phalanx no one had better mess with!! Even today, Mystical is in close contact with the wife of our (now deceased) Command Sgt Major from Germany, who helped her so much, and is like a second mother to her. Unit Wives Support Groups are definitely Life and Marriage Saver/Saviors!! Mystical (happily) with the boy in Germany - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by DSTremf: Well I think the wives don't get much attention. In some ways it is probbly harder on them since they don't know what is going on where their spouse is in the combat zone. One of the COMPASS mentors at our base has a saying that each deployment can be your easiest and your worst. Each deployment is different and effects the family differently. I also believe that it is the same for the couple. For each person there are aspects of a deployment that are easier and some that are worse. The very worst thing either person can do is focus on the negative and play the "grass is greener" game. My husband and I acknowledge that we each have good days and bad days and even if we are half a world apart we try to be there for each other and support each other. While we don't get the big kudos or the parades I do believe that there are many people out there ready to support the spouses but just don't know how. I don't need the kudos or the parades, I just need people to be my friends and be there when I have a bad day. I need friends that will take care of my kids either when I go to meet my husband or if there is an emergency. I need people that can be the taxi driver for my kids when I can't. And guess what, in over 24 years of being a Navy wife I have found that from both civilian and military friends. Kathy

content: Maybe it's just me, or maybe it's because I was raised by a Military Wife... but what kind of support are you looking for exactly? Other wives? Your husband? Look, don't expect your husband to appreciate everything that you do with flowers/candy or praises. You're a military wife and it is expected of you to hold down the house while your husband is away. You're expected to be both Mom and Dad, have six pairs of arms, and be happy and cheerful even if you're 7 months pregnant with the flu. That's just how life is in the military. And while it may "SUCK", you signed up for it when you married him (or when he signed up, depending on which came first). So I hate to be one to say it, but you're not the only one that gets left at home, so buck up.
